title-group.article-title: Control versus Firm Value: The Impact of Restrictions on Foreign Share Ownership

abstract.p: This study investigates the impact of foreign ownership restrictions on firm value. A unique event on the Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) simultaneously tightened and relaxed such restrictions. I find that imposing (relaxing) such restrictions reduces (increases) firm value. I identify some explanatory factors for the cross-sectional variation of the premium on foreign shares. Firm size appears to be an efficient signal for information availability. The firm-size effect subsumes liquidity and volatility effects. Our findings have implications for governments, government-linked companies, and private corporations that have in place or are considering self-imposed restrictions on foreign ownership of their stocks.
